dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB BROADHEAD positions a heavy-duty DRILL and BORES INTO ROCK. A cloud of thick black DUST quickly envelops him. H releases the trigger. Waits. The dust clears revealing a JAGGED HOLE cut in the stone Bob turns quickly. Gestures. A NERVOUS MAN steps into the artificial light. In contras to Bob, his face is hidden behind an enormous BREATHING M and through the thick lenses we see two very frightened e He carries EXPLOSIVE CHARGES. Bob takes the first charge and slides it into the jagged opening. Flips the switch-- A light on the explosive BLIPS ON, primed, and ready to b They move down the wall and repeat the procedure, setting half-a-dozen explosives into an equal number of newly-dri holes, flipping the switches. Bob slips the last charge into the stone and pauses. Look at his associate. The bulky mask amplifies the man’s erra BREATHING. Bob flips the final switch. Across the entire length of the rock face, the charge lights start to BLINK They turn and run like hell-- Bob hurries across the loose NARROW BOARDS serving as flo in the tunnel. The nervous man slips off the planks into muck. Bob hoists him out and they duck into a nearby RECE The blinking lights STOP and: THE EXPLOSION SHAKES THE WALLS around them. DUST AND DEBR BLASTS down the length of the tunnel and blocks out the v Slowly the dust begins to clear. Bob looks around. Listen The nervous man is too scared to move. His eyes shift lef and right. Finally he pulls off his mask, a relieved smil spreading over his face. He turns to Bob. Starts to speak Bob gestures at him. Quiet! From somewhere deep in the rock, there comes an eerie RUM  2. Bob grabs him, and they run. DIRT AND SHALE POURS from th ceiling in thick columns and Suddenly the ROOF GIVES WAY and they are both BURIED ALIV Only Bob’s hand reaches out of the dirt, searching for a grip, grasping at the shale-- Inch-by-inch Bob slowly pulls himself out, his head first then his shoulders, torso. But he isn’t alone. Using all his strength and willpower, Bob pulls the other man free They lie on the floor of the tunnel, exhausted, covered i dirt, GASPING for breath and The walls GROAN even louder-- Bob and his associate crawl across the floor of the tunne but slowly. Much too slowly. MORE COLUMNS OF DIRT begin to form. The men drag themselv onto a small metal PLATFORM as the remainder of the TUNNE COLLAPSES in a storm of rock. Bob reaches up, searching for a RED BUTTON. He finds it a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB holds on as the platform SHOOTS UPWARD through a narr shaft of rock. He struggles to stand. This is an open lif and the walls of the shaft RACE PAST AT HIGH SPEED. Stick out your arm and you lose it. Slowly the NERVOUS MAN stirs. He tries to get up too, but his legs give out. He slips: His face stops less than an inch from the shaft wall spee past. Bob caught him. The man stares down at his own nose We see the TIP IS SCRAPED and The elevator suddenly STOPS--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB and the NERVOUS MAN are thrown out onto the surface, immediately react to the sun. They are in the middle of a working mine. BIG LOADERS RUM PAST. The surrounding landscape is a dead, strip-mined he Bob sits up. Dirt and rocks slide off him. His face looks like it may never wash clean. He tries to say something b  Suddenly a big WHISTLE BLOWS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB stands in a long ambling line with other FILTHY MINER He reaches the TIME CLOCK, inserts his CARD, and PUNCHES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grungy television displays today’s WINNING LOTTERY NUMB The BARTENDER begins to channel surf. We catch a glimpse a bizarre alien SPACESHIP. A COMMERCIAL asks, “Looking fo adventure?” A handsome NEWS ANCHOR says, “Scientists stil cannot explain--” A SMILING MAN surrounded by MONEY adds, went to outer space and all I brought back was a FORTUNE. An EXCITABLE CROWD chants a word we hear for the first ti “HEECHEE!” BOB sits on his usual stool and stares into the broken mi behind the bar, his EMPTY BEER BOTTLES speedily accumulat TWO MINERS step up to the bar next to Bob and catch the B sliding their way. They raise the bottles...but then noti

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: You all right, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: Of course he’s all right. That is Bob Broadhead you’re talkin’ about!

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: Then why does he look like that?

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: All contemplative like... In unison they look in the mirror and study Bob’s express

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: That is not a contemplating face.

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: The hell it isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When have you ever contemplated anything?

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: Plenty o’ times.

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: Ten bucks says Bob is in an advanced state of contemplation right now.

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: You’re on. They wait for him to speak... and wait. Bob clutches a be obviously intoxicated, studying his reflection. Now he lo ready to say something. His friends lean close, and final

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Started working the food mines at half-pay, age twelve... The first miner smiles wide. The loser reaches deep insid his pocket, and hands over his oily crumpled ten dollar B BOB (CONT’D) By the time I was sixteen, had my rating: charge driver.

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: Your folks would be real proud of you, Bob. That’s hard work, and good pay--

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah. Good pay... but what do you do with it?

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It’s not enough to get you out.

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: Out of what? Their FOREMAN steps up to the bar, the soot on his face b now a permanent feature. He doesn’t seem to like Bob much Clearly, the feeling’s mutual:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griping, Broadhead?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Drinkin’.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Close call today--

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Think so?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Your charges were too close.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: My charges were fine. We're drillin’ too deep, too fast.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Oh is that right? Maybe you oughta file a complaint with management. Bob finds that funny, and LAUGHS in his beer. The foreman isn’t amused. He moves close:

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: I can tell your future, Bob. One day, maybe real soon, your luck will run out, and you'll find yourself under a couple tons o’ loose shale. Oh...we’ll get you out. We don’t leave our people. of course, it may take a while. The two miners closest to Bob are beginning to look worri expecting the worst. Everybody within earshot is listenin

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I reckon you know all about waitin’. How long was your daddy trapped in that cave-in? Must be hard on a kid. Is it true what they say, after a man’s been buried more than three days, he’s just not good for anything anymore-- Bob turns on the foreman and lands an old-fashioned PUNCH that drops him to the floor. You could hear a pin drop. Bob stares down at his limp bo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drinks on me. Everybody CHEERS. MALE AND FEMALE MINERS rush the bar for their free drinks, while Bob makes his way toward the str His two friends share a worried look and follow close beh

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: You can’t just punch out the boss, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Too late...

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: All of this contemplation is messin’ with the inner- workings of your brain! Bob stops at the screen door. He stares out at the night

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I have never seen things more clearly, boys. For the first time in my life, I can decide for myself.

dialogues.speaker: MINER
dialogues.text: Decide what, Bob? Bob turns around and looks at them, with such an expressi they have to know this is the last time they’1l ever see

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Who I want to be tomorrow. And Bob pushes out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB walks away from the place, unsteady at first, but qui picking up the pace. SOUNDS OF THE BAR fade. Bob reaches the road and keeps on going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tired BOB leaves the long stretch of pavement for a sma building plastered with POSTERS that read: “Join the Star Rush,” “Find the Lost Alien Race” and “Plunder the Univer  7. Nevertheless Bob stares at one sign in particular: “CLOSE That settles it. His legs give out from under him, and Bo falls face down in the dirt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is rising in the sky. BOB hasn’t moved an inch, still lying on the ground, when a VEHICLE pulls up to the building and parks. We hear the sound of a CAR DOOR openi A PAIR OF LEGS walks across the dirt and gravel right pas Bob, not even hesitating. We hear the sound of KEYS, the FRONT DOOR swinging open, and a second later it BANGING S Moments pass. Bob lies there. The DOOR opens again. The same FOOTSTEPS cross gravel. No THE LEGS return, and stand by Bob. We never do see his fa

dialogues.speaker: RECRUITMENT GUY
dialogues.text: (bored, by rote) Earth not doin’ right by you? Hope the stars will treat you better? If you answer yes to the above, then fame, fortune, and adventure can be yours-- Go and search the cosmos for fantastic discoveries that defy imagination, priceless objects older than humanity, and maybe even find an alien or two.... Bob doesn’t move an inch. Is he even awake? We don’t know

dialogues.speaker: RECRUITMENT GUY
dialogues.text: Passage off planet ain’t cheap. Bob moves his arm and only his arm, searching around in h pocket, and finally coming up with one simple LOTTERY TIC The ticket is FLASHING repeatedly: “WINNER! WINNER! WINNE The man accepts the ticket. A second later, he reaches ba down for Bob’s thumb, pressing the digit against a small HANDHELD DEVICE. It BEEPS and

dialogues.speaker: RECRUITMENT GUY
dialogues.text: The human race thanks you. The legs leave. We hear the sound of FOOTSTEPS on gravel. The door re-opens and BANGS SHUT. Bob just lies in the di

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled) You’re welcome. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next generation of EARTH SHUTTLE crosses a sea of sta cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB and the other NEW ARRIVALS lie strapped side-by-side zero-gravity WEBBING. The passenger cabin is crammed full everyone packed in tight; and unfortunately for Bob, he i stuck next to a woman named SHERI, who never stops talkin

dialogues.speaker: SHERI
dialogues.text: Are you scared? Not me, I mean, I know why I should be scared: We’re going to climb into space- ships built by aliens before we were born -- before anyone was born -- strap ourselves in, and hit “go.” We’ll travel faster than light, we don’t know how... We don’t know how long we’1ll be gone, even if we knew where we were going, which we don’t. So we could travel our whole lives and die before we get there, or run into something that will kill us in two seconds-- Right? Right. (short pause) Are you scared? Bob watches a uniformed CREW MEMBER float past directly a them, moving smoothly through the cabin. He grins knowing

dialogues.speaker: CREW MEMBER
dialogues.text: Docking in 5 minutes. Welcome to Gateway!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shuttle approaches a large ASTEROID. It looks lumpy, charred, and pockmarked with craters. An ancient space ro But the craters on this asteroid berth STARSHIPS.  9. We see only the nose of the ships as the great rock rotat giving us a long look at what’s become our “gateway” to t stars... curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB and the other NEW ARRIVALS walk a narrow lane formed two ROWS OF SHIPS, charred and battered like ancient reli but somehow still beautiful. The exotic lines of the alie design defy normal Earthly expectations of space or rocke Bob can’t take his eyes off the ships. Up ahead, SECURITY PERSONNEL are tossing INFORMATION PACKETS the size of sev phone books into the waiting arms of the awestruck newcom Assistant Director EMMA FOTHER steps out onto a small BAL and addresses the group. Unlike most of the others on thi asteroid, Emma is always well-groomed and impeccably dres

dialogues.speaker: EMMA
dialogues.text: “Welcome aboard.” (short pause) That was a joke, but you won’t understand it for some time... The information packet you are being given contains your room assignment; a daily per-capita tax assessment for the air you are already breathing; and a copy of your contract granting the Gateway Corporation sole authority in the exploitation, sale, and lease of any and all discoveries you make during your missions into outer space. Bob moves forward, catches the packet tossed his way, and immediately looks around for something. He seems to find

dialogues.speaker: EMMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is vital that you do not lose your information packet-- Emma sees Bob throw his information packet INTO A GARBAGE CAN. She stops talking. Bob senses he was observed, looks up, and locks eyes with Emma. Clearly she hates him alrea Bob looks back at the starships one last time, then walks  10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB steps into a maze of tunnels constructed from a stran luminescent alien metal that emits its own light. These passages wind crazily through the rock and are always CRO with prospectors, security guards, and maintenance person He reads the CARD with his room number, scans a colorful on the wall, and starts off-- But Bob doesn’t go unnoticed. DANE METCHNIKOV is small an rodent-like. He locks onto Bob and scurries up beside him even creepier when he smiles:

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: Greetings, friend! Bob glances down at him. Says nothing at all. Keeps movin

dialogues.speaker: DANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Name’s Dane Metchnikov, guide and financial advisor, 1-stop shop for off-Earth contraband, trustworthy confidant and all- around orientation specialist. (short pause) If you’1ll follow me this way, I’1l be happy to-- Bob heads in the other direction and Dane looks disappoin

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: --or that way, sure. Bob and Dane pass a SCREEN playing images of Gateway. A soothing female voice offers:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OF GATEWAY
dialogues.text: Gateway is an artifact created by the ancient Heechee race. It was formed around an asteroid or the core of an atypical comet-- The NEXT SCREEN they pass by is giving the same presentat

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OF GATEWAY
dialogues.text: The time of its creation is not known, but almost surely precedes the rise of human civilization! Bob keeps moving down the tunnel. Dane struggles to keep  11.

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: I’ve helped a lot of new fish -..no offense...transition to life on a hunk o’ space rock.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Don’t need your help. I spent most of my days in tunnels just like-- An UNIDENTIFIED FLYING OBJECT enters the tunnel. It looks like a metal ball with little folded bug arms. The thing speeds through the corridor. Everybody ducks out of the w It whizzes between Bob and Dane, and darts around the cor BOB (CONT’D) The hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: Now this is exactly what I am talkin’ about. For a small retainer, a token fee, I can be available to answer questions such as, “the hell was that?” Bob grabs Dane by the shirt and pulls him close. Scares h

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: How about you answer for free?

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: Sure, you want to sample the product before buying-- I understand completely. That is just good business sense!

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (again, stronger) The hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: I don’t know-- Bob starts down the tunnel. Dane follows, trying to expla

dialogues.speaker: DANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nobody knows!

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What do you mean nobody knows?  12.

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: The aliens left it. It just flies around, and as far as anybody can tell, doesn’t do anything-- You can’t catch it, and it never stops. My own personal theory is, it’s an air freshener.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The air stinks-- Bob steps inside a bizarre ELEVATOR. Dane squeezes in, fa

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: How do you know, maybe that’s the smell o’ Heechee flowers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB and DANE huddle inside a claustrophobic elevator neve meant to carry occupants the size and shape of human bein Dane stares up at Bob, expectantly. If he had a tail, he’ be wagging it. Finally Bob gives in. He reaches into his pocket and takes out a TWENTY. Dane grabs the bill fast, crumples it, pulls it, and hold up to the light while he says:

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: Everyone who comes to Gateway gets ten days’ worth of food, lodging, and air -- courtesy of the Gateway Corporation -- plus an invitation to sign up for the next spaceship out. You don’t have to sign up for the next prospecting trip, or any trip at all. If you lose your nerve, you can stay here until your money runs out... The elevator doors slide OPEN. Immediately Bob hears SCREAMS. SECURITY GUARDS are draggi a STRUGGLING MAN toward an open AIRLOCK. They throw him i One of the guards hits a switch, the thick airlock door slides shut, and a moment later we see the terrified man the small window, POUNDING on the glass and YELLING for h  13. Bob watches the scene intensely, hardened enough by life death doesn’t shock him, but even this takes getting used

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (dryly) Looks like his money ran out. The outer hatch BLOWS OPEN and the man is suddenly PULLED FROM THE WINDOW -- as if by an invisible hand -- just a b Through the porthole we briefly glimpse the man’s unprote body HURLING TOWARD THE STARS. Dane squeezes closer making room for OTHERS trying to get

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: You go bust, you take the next shuttle home. Try to run...you get the airlock. The elevator slides SHUT. It really is very cramped in he Dane stands next to a HEAVY-SET NURSE transporting a high tech BIOLOGICAL CONTAINER. About the size of a large buck A SCREEN in the elevator displays the Gateway CORPORATE L

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OF GATEWAY
dialogues.text: Gateway is proud to announce the return of mission 24-331 ..-another successful voyage into the unknown!

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: That means the ship returned. It doesn’t say anything about the condition of the crew.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What happened to the crew?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (gruffly) You’re lookin’ at ‘em. The elevator OPENS and the nurse EXITS carrying her medic bucket. Bob watches her go. Slowly the doors begin to shu

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: “Successful” is defined kind of loosely around here-- curt TO:  14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator OPENS on a different level. BOB starts down tunnel and scans the room numbers, with DANE right alongs

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: They probably dropped out of warp too close to a sun, or a supernova. Best not to think about it. Besides, I’ve been out three times, and look at me: sound of mind and body!

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. They pass several more SCREENS with ACTORS SIGNING DOCUME

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OF GATEWAY
dialogues.text: Upon your arrival on Gateway, remember to read and sign your Memorandum of Agreement-- Now the same actors in SPACESUITS are finding fake-lookin ARTIFACTS on a staged planet.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OF GATEWAY
dialogues.text: --releasing all rights in and to any discoveries, artifacts, and objects of value you find during exploration-- The actors hand them over to COMPANY OFFICIALS, shake han and receive OVERSIZED CHECKS.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OF GATEWAY
dialogues.text: --to the Gateway Authority! They find a door. Bob stops.

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: Guys like you and me? We feed off danger. I’m just biding my time waitin’ for the right mission to come along, eyes on the big score, you know? I’11 leave here a wealthy man.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: If you say so. There is a DEAFENING BLAST, and the tunnel lurches, as if  15. asteroid is breaking apart....

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: That was--

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (realizing) --a ship taking off.

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: Yeah, you'll feel that a lot. Bob moves toward his room, and the door opens automatical

dialogues.speaker: DANE
dialogues.text: You reckon maybe I should wait outside your door a while in case you need me-- Bob shoves another BILL into Dane’s hand, and walks into room. The door slides shut. A happy Dane examines his cas

dialogues.speaker: DANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can’t stay, very busy, gotta run! INT. BOB’S QUARTERS -- DAY BOB stands inside of his room. Literally, standing in pla is all he can do. Bob’s room is the SIZE OF A SMALL CLOSE There is a sleeping bag hanging on the wall, assuming he fall asleep vertically. A miniscule sink and a funny toil that retracts. Hooks and slots for his things. He has abo six inches of wiggle room between his shoulders and the w A tiny private SCREEN BLIPS ON with a close-up of an EYEB

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OF GATEWAY
dialogues.text: Gateway not what you expected? Experiencing feelings of profound regret? Let the Sigfrid-1000 Automated Psycho-analyst help! For the first time we see Bob smile, and LAUGH. Something tells us he has never looked this happy in his entire lif

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No thanks, darlin’. I’m good. I’m real good.  16. INT. “THE BLUE HELL” -- NIGHT Ragged-looking PROSPECTORS guzzle down cheap BOOZE at the long bar. Space-adapted gaming tables showcase POKER, a s moving ROULETTE with a big dense ball, and CRAPS with dic that take forever to stop. A dozen DIFFERENT LANGUAGES ca be heard mixed together--English, Russian, Chinese, Spani and everyone talks animatedly, as if trying to be underst BOB walks through the swinging doors, as if stepping into wild west. He looks around.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: And now, my dear friends and fools, let us speak of bigger rewards -- and of a bonus the company never expects to pay. Bob wants to hear this and squeezes through the crowd to PROFESSOR HEGRAMET sits at a table holding a BEER, surrou by his REGULAR AUDIENCE of half-drunk/half-alert prospect

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Five hundred million dollars for that lucky man or woman who finds a living Heechee-- Everyone gathered around BLURTS a positive guttural respo

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: You! Answer me this. What did the Heechee look like?

dialogues.speaker: MALE PROSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Beats me.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Of course it does -- because we’ve never found anything resembling a photograph or a drawing. Now tell me: Did they have some system for storing knowledge? Did they have books? Did they write?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE PROSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Surely, they must have. What that system was, we simply don’t know. Now tell me, what is the biggest mystery of all?  17. Everybody stands there, perplexed, hiding behind their be Bob isn’t one to speak up, but something about this gets

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The Heechee didn’t die here-- The Professor finds Bob and looks him over. Seems surpris

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: And why not?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Because if they did, we’d find their bones...or whatever they had instead of bones.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: A worthy observation. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: If they didn’t die, then they left. So I guess the big mystery is, why did the Heechee leave all this for us to find ...and where did they go?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Brilliant. That is the very question which compelled me to leave the confines of the classroom and venture out to the wilds of Gateway itself! The Professor takes a drink. Everyone stands around waiti for him to continue, but he never does, and finally Bob a

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: So where are they?

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: My dear fellow, it beats the piss out of me. He sets his head face down on the table. Class dismissed. Everyone disperses. Bob looks like he should have known better. He makes his way to the bar and takes an open sto A group of DRUNKEN PROSPECTORS lift up their bottles in s

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKS
dialogues.text: We get squashed, burned, and shredded to bits -- we don’t care which -- little lost Heechee start making us rich!  18. The BARTENDER slides a BEER to Bob. He nods thanks and raises the bottle to his lips when he is shoved from behi Bob turns and sees an ENORMOUS MAN standing behind him. T giant has a problem with Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You’re sittin’ in his seat. Bob thinks about it. Doesn’t want any trouble. He starts leave -- and gets shoved again. The enormous man glares d at Bob, but doesn’t say anything. Hell, maybe he can’t ta

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: He wants to make an example of you to warn others. The giant wraps his thick fingers around Bob’s beer, take from him, and tosses the bottle over his shoulder. Bob watches his beer sail away... The bottle rises into the air, and just when you think it going to fall back down, IT KEEPS RISING. The beer tumble end-over-end through the cave like it’s never coming back

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (surprised) My beer-- The bartender SPITS into a dirty glass and casually expla

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Right up there is the center of the asteroid. The center doesn’t spin. The giant rolls up his sleeves, getting ready to pummel B

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No spin, no gravity, gotcha. The enormous man lunges and misses. Bob evades the blow a leaps onto a table, from the table onto the giant’s back, LAUNCHING HIMSELF IN THE AIR. Bob jumps high above the tavern floor...and never comes d Everyone in the bar looks up, sees him, and CHEERS WILDLY

dialogues.speaker: BOB RISES HIGHER AND HIGHER--
dialogues.text: He floats through the cavern over the saloon, pleased wit himself and his great escape. The enormous man watches Bob go, disappointed. He sits do  19. Gradually everybody returns to their drinks or to the gam For Bob, realization sets in--

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. Bob drifts in the zero-gravity, STARTING TO SPIN a little unable to stop his slow tumble and with nothing to grab o

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Looks like I got me a floater. Bob looks around, the best he can. Where did that come fr

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Who said that?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: I did. Out of the deep dark shadows of the cavern, a figure emer KLARA MOYNLIN is a strong-faced woman, her hair pulled ba tight, sailing through the air.

dialogues.speaker: KLARA
dialogues.text: Relax your body.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What-- KLARA SLAMS INTO BOB and knocks the wind out of him. They fly through the core together, one of her arms wrapped ar him, the other extended out in front of her like a lifegu Bob recovers. Holds her tight.

dialogues.speaker: KLARA
dialogues.text: Have you ever been with a woman?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Uh-huh--
